title: NYPD swears in diverse group of 678 new recruits
text:

The class is 10% Asian. Previous Next Enlarge Meet the new cops, not the same as the old cops.
Diversity was on display Thursday as the NYPD welcomed 678 new graduates into it ranks — a squad that that draws talent "from every great neighborhood" and from all immigrant groups, Mayor de Blasio said.
“This class is one of the most diverse in the history of New York City,” the mayor said.
Police Commissioner Bill Bratton, at the swearing-in ceremony at the NYPD’s new state-of-the-art academy in College Point, Queens, recalled that when he joined the Boston Police Department 45 years ago there were no women in class of 155.
There were also no openly gay officers, just two black cops, and one Hispanic officer.
“Times have changed,” Bratton said. “You are joining a department that is openly proud of our gay officers, of our transsexual officers ... times have changed so much for the better."
The mission, however, remains the same, he added.
James Keivom/New York Daily News “You are joining a department that is openly proud of our gay officers, of our transsexual officers ... times have changed so much for the better," Bill Bratton said at the ceremony. "It’s a sacred trust,” Bratton said.
In closing, the top cop cited the bravery of the NYPD officers who survived a gun battle overnight in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, with a trio of armed suspects.
“They didn't run away,” Bratton said. “They went toward the danger. They faced the danger.”
The new NYPD class is 80% male, but less than half of the new recruits are white.
The new class is 32% Hispanic but only 12.6% black — a number that falls short of Bratton’s promise of bringing more African-Americans into the department. The class is 10% Asian.
Just over half of the new cops are city residents.
James Keivom/New York Daily News New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio, center, and NYPD Commissioner Bill Bratton, left, smile during the swearing-in ceremony. Of the new recruits, 151 are immigrants who hail from 36 different countries and speak 22 different languages. Sixty are veterans, 252 have bachelor’s degrees, and 14 have master’s degrees.
One recruit is a lawyer. Another is former New York Post reporter Natasha Velez, whose grandfather Miguel Velez was an NYPD officer for 21 years and survived being shot on the job.
Bratton stirred controversy in June when he told The Guardian newspaper he had a hard time hiring black cops because too many black people have criminal records.
He also said that relations between the NYPD and black residents were badly frayed long before he took over.
Since then, Bratton has made a commitment to double the number of black cadets in the Police Academy over the next year and has order the NYPD to find ways of streamlining the hiring process.
De Blasio has also actively encouraged more minority New Yorkers to apply for jobs with the police department.
